content.text: Remove the lid from beaker A
Pour \(150 \text{cm}^3\) of hot water into beaker A and replace the lid
Place the thermometer in the water in beaker A
In the first row of Table 1.1, record the temperature \(\theta\) of the water at \(t = 0\) and immediately start the stop-clock

Record, in Table 1.1, the temperature \(\theta\) of the water at times \(t = 30 \text{s}\), \(t = 60 \text{s}\), \(t = 90 \text{s}\), \(t = 120 \text{s}\), \(t = 150 \text{s}\) and \(t = 180 \text{s}\)
Remove the thermometer from the beaker
Repeat (a) for beaker B
Add units to the column headings in Table 1.1
Write a conclusion stating whether the insulation affects the rate of cooling of the water. Justify your answer by reference to values from your results
Calculate the average cooling rate \(x_{1}\) during the first half of the experiment for the water in beaker B. Use your readings for beaker B from Table 1.1 and the equation
where \(T = 90 \text{s}\) and \(\theta_0\) and \(\theta_{90}\) are the temperatures of the water in beaker B at \(t = 0\) and \(t = 90 \text{s}\)
Include the unit
Calculate the average cooling rate \(x_{2}\) during the second half of the experiment for the water in beaker B. Use your readings for beaker B from Table 1.1 and the equation
where \(T = 90 \text{s}\) and \(\theta_{90}\) and \(\theta_{180}\) are the temperatures of the water in beaker B at \(t = 90 \text{s}\) and \(t = 180 \text{s}\)
Include the unit
Suggest an additional experiment to test whether the lid affects the cooling rate of the water in beaker B. State how the readings are used to show the effect
You are **not** required to carry out this additional experiment
A student suggests that the temperature of the water in beaker B at \(t = 0\) for this additional experiment must be the same as in **(b)(i)** for the comparison to be fair
State whether your results support this suggestion
Use your results from **(d)** to explain whether this precaution is necessary
statement
explanation
In this experiment, you will investigate the effect of insulation on the cooling of water
Carry out the following instructions, referring to Fig. 1.1
Beaker A is covered with material that is a thermal insulator
Beaker B is identical to beaker A but has no insulation
Connect the crocodile clip to a length \(l = 90.0 \text{cm}\) of resistance wire A
Close the switch
Measure, and record in Table 2.1, the value of potential difference (p.d.) \(V\) and current \(I\) for the wire
Open the switch
Calculate, and record in Table 2.1, the resistance \(R\) of \(90.0 \text{cm}\) of wire A
Use your values of \(V\) and \(I\) and the equation
Repeat step (a) for \(l = 90.0 \text{cm}\) of wire B, \(l = 50.0 \text{cm}\) of wire A and \(l = 50.0 \text{cm}\) of wire B
Complete the headings in Table 2.1
Calculate a value \(P\) using your results from Table 2.1 and the equation

content.blockMath: \[P = \frac{R \text{ for } 90.0 \text{ cm of wire A}}{R \text{ for } 90.0 \text{ cm of wire B}}.\]

content.text: Calculate a value \(Q\) using your results from Table 2.1 and the equation

content.blockMath: \[Q = \frac{R \text{ for } 50.0 \text{ cm of wire A}}{R \text{ for } 50.0 \text{ cm of wire B}}.\]

content.text: A student suggests that the values of \(P\) and \(Q\) should be equal
State whether your results support this suggestion. Justify your answer by reference to values from your results
statement
justification
Suggest one reason why students all doing this experiment carefully with the same apparatus may not obtain the same results
In this experiment, you will compare the resistances of two wires
The circuit has been set up for you
Carry out the following instructions, referring to Fig. 2.1
Measure and record the height \(h_{\mathrm{O}}\) of the triangular object
\(h_{\mathrm{O}} = .........\mathrm{cm}\)
Place the lens a distance \(u = 20.0 \text{cm}\) from the triangular object
Place the screen close to the lens
Switch on the lamp
Move the screen away from the lens until a clear, focused image of the triangular object is seen on the screen
Measure, and record in Table 3.1, the height \(h_{\mathrm{I}}\) of the image
Repeat the procedure for \(u = 25.0 \text{cm}\), \(u = 30.0 \text{cm}\), \(u = 35.0 \text{cm}\) and \(u = 40.0 \text{cm}\)
Switch off the lamp
For each distance \(u\), calculate, and record in Table 3.1, the value of \(\frac{1}{h_{\mathrm{I}}}\)
Plot a graph of \(u / \text{cm}\) (\(y\)-axis) against \(\frac{1}{h_1} /\frac{1}{\text{cm}}\) (x-axis). Start the axes at the origin (0,0)
From your graph, determine \(u_0\), the value of \(u\) when \(\frac{1}{h_1} = 0.0\)
Determine the gradient of the graph
Show clearly on the graph how you obtained the necessary information
gradient = .........
Calculate the focal length \(f\) of the lens. Use your value of \(h_{\mathrm{O}}\) from **(a)** and the equation
where \(G\) is numerically equal to the gradient from **(d)**(ii)
Describe **one** difficulty that can be experienced when measuring the height of the image
Suggest an improvement to overcome this difficulty
difficulty
improvement
In this experiment, you will investigate the image produced by a converging lens
Carry out the following instructions, referring to Fig. 3.1
triangular
object
A student investigates the strength of an electromagnet

The electromagnet is made from a coil of insulated wire wrapped around an iron rod. When there is an electric current in the coil, the iron rod becomes magnetised. The electromagnet can then attract magnetic materials (e.g. iron and steel)
Plan an experiment to investigate how **one** factor affects the number of steel paper clips the electromagnet can support
You are **not** required to carry out the experiment
The apparatus available includes:
an electromagnet, shown in Fig. 4.1
a power supply
a selection of steel paper clips
In your plan, you should:
state a factor which can be measured and list any additional apparatus needed
state the key variables to be kept constant
explain briefly how to do the experiment, including any precautions to ensure reliable results (you may draw a diagram or add to Fig. 4.1 to help your explanation)
draw a table, or tables, with column headings, to show how to display the readings (you are **not** required to enter any readings in the table)
explain how to use the readings to reach a conclusion
